dataset.title: Stormwater Abandoned Manhole - Hamilton City Council
dataset.description:
If you wish to download and consume this entire dataset - click on the link for the file format(s) of your choosing: 

  • FGDB/File Geodatabase 
  • Shapefile 
  • Excel 
  • CAD (DWG) 

Please note that the links above may change at any time. For best practice, please refer to this page for the correct links.   

If any of the links are above are not functioning, please let us know at gis@hcc.govt.nz. 

This Stormwater dataset contains the following layers: 

  • Stormwater Abandoned Main (A stormwater main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network) 
  • Stormwater Abandoned Manhole (An opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe that is still in the ground but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network) 
  • Stormwater Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic stormwater infrastructure as it was actually constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system) 
  • Stormwater Attenuation and Treatment Device (A device used to provide temporary storage and the controlled release of storm water volumes. Located upstream of the receiving environment, devices such as wetlands and ponds may also incorporate a storm water treatment function) 
  • Stormwater Catchpit (A device that collects stormwater run-off from the road and transports it along the network) 
  • Stormwater Catchpit Lead (A pipe that transports stormwater run-off from catchpits and connects into the stormwater network) 
  • Stormwater Channel (An open drain, natural watercourse (such as a stream) or lined channel that collects stormwater run-off from the environment or network) 
  • Stormwater Inlet (A structure where stormwater enters either a pipe, pond, culvert or channel) 
  • Stormwater Main (A pipe that transports stormwater to a natural watercourse or body of water) 
  • Stormwater Manhole (An opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe) 
  • Stormwater Node (A junction point in a pipe. It can be a structure) 
  • Stormwater Outlet (A structure at the end of a pipe or channel that controls the flow of stormwater to a natural watercourse or body of water)
  • Stormwater Service Line (A gravity flow pipeline connecting a building’s direct runoff collection system to a stormwater pipe or a kerb (in the case of kerb and channel connections)) 
  • Stormwater Soakage Trench (A subsurface structure into which runoff is conveyed for disposal by infiltration) 
  • Stormwater Subsoil Drain (A perforated drain used to collect ground water and transport it to a land drainage or stormwater drainage system)  


Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download. 

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz 

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works. 

Hamilton City Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. 

While you are free to crop, export and re-purpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Hamilton City Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include the following statement when distributing any work derived from this data: 

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Hamilton City Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.

  • Stormwater Abandoned Manhole (An opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe that is still in the ground but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network) 
  • Stormwater Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic stormwater infrastructure as it was actually constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system) 
  • Stormwater Attenuation and Treatment Device (A device used to provide temporary storage and the controlled release of storm water volumes. Located upstream of the receiving environment, devices such as wetlands and ponds may also incorporate a storm water treatment function) 
  • Stormwater Catchpit (A device that collects stormwater run-off from the road and transports it along the network) 
  • Stormwater Catchpit Lead (A pipe that transports stormwater run-off from catchpits and connects into the stormwater network) 
  • Stormwater Channel (An open drain, natural watercourse (such as a stream) or lined channel that collects stormwater run-off from the environment or network) 
  • Stormwater Inlet (A structure where stormwater enters either a pipe, pond, culvert or channel) 
  • Stormwater Main (A pipe that transports stormwater to a natural watercourse or body of water) 
  • Stormwater Manhole (An opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe) 
  • Stormwater Node (A junction point in a pipe. It can be a structure) 
  • Stormwater Outlet (A structure at the end of a pipe or channel that controls the flow of stormwater to a natural watercourse or body of water)
  • Stormwater Service Line (A gravity flow pipeline connecting a building’s direct runoff collection system to a stormwater pipe or a kerb (in the case of kerb and channel connections)) 
  • Stormwater Soakage Trench (A subsurface structure into which runoff is conveyed for disposal by infiltration) 
  • Stormwater Subsoil Drain (A perforated drain used to collect ground water and transport it to a land drainage or stormwater drainage system)  


Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download. 

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz 

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works. 

Hamilton City Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. 

While you are free to crop, export and re-purpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Hamilton City Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include the following statement when distributing any work derived from this data: 

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Hamilton City Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.

dataset.title: Traffic Counts - Hamilton City Council
dataset.description:
You may access a GIS viewer that has been set up to view the data by clicking on this LINK.

Hamilton City Council undertakes regular traffic counts at approximately 150 sites throughout the city. This information is used for monitoring trends and planning for new works. 

Some sites are counted continuously and this data is analysed to determine seasonal variations in traffic flows throughout the year. 

Most sites are counted for a seven day period once every one or two years. 

These counts are adjusted using factors derived from the continuous sites and then an estimate of the average daily traffic for the year is made.

dataset.title: Hot Ground Hazard Area
dataset.description:
This layer displays hot ground hazard areas identified in the Taupō District Plan. Geothermal areas have the potential to cause subsidence and can create a number of hazards including subsidence, hot ground and hydrothermal eruptions. Thermal areas can be difficult to define as the boundaries and extent of areas of hot ground can change over time. These thermal areas occur in a number of locations around the District in both rural and urban areas.

The Taupō District Plan has been operative since 2007. Selected datasets from the Taupō District Plan have been made available for download to allow for better public access to the data underlying the plan. Note that some features mapped for district plan purposes may have changed over time. Taupō District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the District Plan data released for public download. The data provided is indicative only and does not purport to be a complete database of all information in Taupō District Council's possession or control. Taupō District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. While you are free to crop, export and repurpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Taupō District Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include this statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

This work is a derivative of the Taupō District Plan. You can view the full Taupō District E-Plan here: https://taupo.isoplan.co.nz/eplan/

dataset.title: Rateable Land Parcel
dataset.description:
This dataset joins the LINZ NZ Parcels dataset with Taupō District Council's rates database, displaying the Valuation ID, Certificate of Title, Rates Unique ID, Legal Description & Supplementary Legal information for a LINZ Parcel ID. Duplicate parcels ID’s represent cases where the parcel is attributed with two or more rating Valuation ID’s. Updates are synced with this dataset weekly from LINZ and every 24 hours from the Taupō District Council rates database.

For more information on the rates process in Taupō, go here: https://www.taupodc.govt.nz/property-and-rates/rates/rating-system-faqs

To search for a rateable property in the Taupō District based on the Valuation ID, go here: http://eservices.taupo.govt.nz/properties/search

The Local Government Rating Act (2002) limits public access to name and postal address information that Council holds for rating purposes. Therefore, ratepayer name and postal address information has not been made available for download. Taupō District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the rateable property data provided. The data provided is indicative only and does not purport to be a complete database of all information in Taupō District Council's possession or control. Taupō District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. While you are free to crop, export and repurpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Taupō District Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include this statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

This work is a derivative of the Taupō District Council Rates database and LINZ Parcel information; it does not purport to be a complete database of all rating information in Taupō District Council's possession or control.

dataset.title: Significant Natural Area
dataset.description:
Significant Natural Areas (SNA) as identified in the Taupō District Plan. Significant Natural Areas are areas of significant indigenous vegetation and/or significant habitats of indigenous fauna that have been identified on the Planning Maps and listed in Schedule 7.8 of the Taupō District Plan. The Council is required to identify and protect significant natural areas under the Resource Management Act 1991. The SigNatID can be used to search for a Significant Natural Area within the E-Plan. Significant Natural Areas were identified within Plan Changes 24 and 25 in June, 2013.

dataset.description:

dataset.title: Storm Water Pumpstation
dataset.description:
The information is extracted from the asset inventory database, Asset-Finda on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from 'As Built Diagrams' and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently. Waikato District Alliance holds storm water asset information for all assets under the road pavement. Waikato Regional Council holds further asset information in all the rural areas.


The primary purpose of this inventory is for asset valuations. The inventory is utilised in forward works and capital work planning. Information on Storm water assets for service requests is displayed on 3 Waters map. The storm water network is an integral part of the land use and consents process, however site visits should be done to validate the status, position and condition of assets.

The information is extracted from the asset inventory database (Asset-Finda) on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from as built diagrams and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently. Waikato District Alliance holds storm water asset information for all assets under the road pavement. Waikato Regional Council holds further asset information in all the rural areas


The primary purpose of this inventory is for asset valuations. The inventory is utilised in forward works and capital work planning. Information on Storm water assets for service requests is displayed on 3 Waters map. The storm water network is an integral part of the land use and consents process, however site visits should be done to validate the status, position and condition of assets.

dataset.title: Storm Water Point
dataset.description:
The information is extracted from the asset inventory database, Asset-Finda on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from 'As Built Diagrams' and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently. Waikato District Alliance holds storm water asset information for all assets under the road pavement. Waikato Regional Council holds further asset information in all the rural areas.


The primary purpose of this inventory is for asset valuations. The inventory is utilised in forward works and capital work planning. Information on Storm water assets for service requests is displayed on 3 Waters map. The storm water network is an integral part of the land use and consents process, however site visits should be done to validate the status, position and condition of assets.

dataset.title: Water Valve - Hamilton City Council
dataset.description:
This layer is part of Hamilton City Council's Freshwater Dataset.

If you wish to download and consume this entire dataset - click on the link for the file format(s) of your choosing:

  • FGDB/File Geodatabase
  • Shapefile
  • Excel
  • CAD (DWG)

Please note that the links above may change at any time. For best practice, please refer to this page for the correct links. 

If any of the links are above are not functioning, please let us know at gis@hcc.govt.nz.

This Water (Freshwater) dataset contains the following layers:

  • Water Valve (A tap on a main that controls the flow of water along that main)
  • Water Service Valve (A tap on a service line that controls the flow of water along that line)
  • Water Service Line/Connection (A pipe that delivers water from the main to a building for consumption)
  • Water Meter (A device that measures and displays the amount of water passing through the associated main or service line)
  • Water Main Offset (A point along a main indicating the distance of the main from another known point such as the property boundary or kerb)
  • Water Main Crossover Junction (The junction of one or more pipes where the pipes do not intersect - aka crossover junction)
  • Water Main Abandoned (A water main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Water Hydrant (A tap supplying access to high-pressure water to fight fires, flush pipes and fill water trucks)
  • Water Chamber MH (An opening/structure in a water chamber for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the chamber)
  • Water Chamber (A chamber on a water main (except bulk mains) containing operational or monitoring devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing operational devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM AV Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing an air valve)
  • Water Backflow Device (A device which prevents the accidental backflow of contaminated water into the water system)
  • Water Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic water infrastructure as it was constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system)

Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download.

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

Hamilton City Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data.

While you are free to crop, export and re-purpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Hamilton City Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include the following statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Hamilton City Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.'

If you wish to download and consume this entire dataset - click on the link for the file format(s) of your choosing:

  • FGDB/File Geodatabase
  • Shapefile
  • Excel
  • CAD (DWG)

Please note that the links above may change at any time. For best practice, please refer to this page for the correct links. 

If any of the links are above are not functioning, please let us know at gis@hcc.govt.nz.

This Water (Freshwater) dataset contains the following layers:

  • Water Valve (A tap on a main that controls the flow of water along that main)
  • Water Service Valve (A tap on a service line that controls the flow of water along that line)
  • Water Service Line/Connection (A pipe that delivers water from the main to a building for consumption)
  • Water Meter (A device that measures and displays the amount of water passing through the associated main or service line)
  • Water Main Offset (A point along a main indicating the distance of the main from another known point such as the property boundary or kerb)
  • Water Main Crossover Junction (The junction of one or more pipes where the pipes do not intersect - aka crossover junction)
  • Water Main Abandoned (A water main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Water Hydrant (A tap supplying access to high-pressure water to fight fires, flush pipes and fill water trucks)
  • Water Chamber MH (An opening/structure in a water chamber for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the chamber)
  • Water Chamber (A chamber on a water main (except bulk mains) containing operational or monitoring devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing operational devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM AV Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing an air valve)
  • Water Backflow Device (A device which prevents the accidental backflow of contaminated water into the water system)
  • Water Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic water infrastructure as it was constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system)

Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download.

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

Hamilton City Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data.

While you are free to crop, export and re-purpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Hamilton City Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include the following statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Hamilton City Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.'

This Water (Freshwater) dataset contains the following layers:

  • Water Valve (A tap on a main that controls the flow of water along that main)
  • Water Service Valve (A tap on a service line that controls the flow of water along that line)
  • Water Service Line/Connection (A pipe that delivers water from the main to a building for consumption)
  • Water Meter (A device that measures and displays the amount of water passing through the associated main or service line)
  • Water Main Offset (A point along a main indicating the distance of the main from another known point such as the property boundary or kerb)
  • Water Main Crossover Junction (The junction of one or more pipes where the pipes do not intersect - aka crossover junction)
  • Water Main Abandoned (A water main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Water Hydrant (A tap supplying access to high-pressure water to fight fires, flush pipes and fill water trucks)
  • Water Chamber MH (An opening/structure in a water chamber for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the chamber)
  • Water Chamber (A chamber on a water main (except bulk mains) containing operational or monitoring devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing operational devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM AV Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing an air valve)
  • Water Backflow Device (A device which prevents the accidental backflow of contaminated water into the water system)
  • Water Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic water infrastructure as it was constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system)

Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download.

This Wastewater dataset contains the following layers:

  • Wastewater Abandoned Manhole (A wastewater manhole that is still in the ground but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Wastewater Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic wastewater infrastructure as it was actually constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system)
  • Wastewater Main (A pipe that receives wastewater from domestic and industrial sources and directs it toward the wastewater treatment plant)
  • Wastewater Manhole (An underground structure built over an opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe)
  • Wastewater Node (A junction point in a pipe It can be a structure)
  • Wastewater Pump Station (A facility that raises wastewater from areas too low to drain by gravity, into existing pipes)
  • Wastewater Service Line (A gravity or pressure flow pipeline connecting a building’s wastewater system to a wastewater main)
  • Wastewater Storage Unit (A device used to contain or store effluent)
  • Wastewater Valve (A wastewater valve is used to shut off or regulate the flow of wastewater)

  • Wastewater Node (A junction point in a pipe It can be a structure)
  • Wastewater Pump Station (A facility that raises wastewater from areas too low to drain by gravity, into existing pipes)
  • Wastewater Service Line (A gravity or pressure flow pipeline connecting a building’s wastewater system to a wastewater main)
  • Wastewater Storage Unit (A device used to contain or store effluent)
  • Wastewater Valve (A wastewater valve is used to shut off or regulate the flow of wastewater)

 

Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download.

dataset.title: Speed limit Bylaw
dataset.description: Speed Limit data is obtained from road position measurements. The most accurate representation of the extent of each speed zone is by the road position measurement. The spatial data presented here has been converted to a 2 dimensional representation and as such has reduced accuracy. The attribute 'Enforcement' shows the date in which the speed limit change was initiated. The speed limits are review information can be obtained here https://www.waikatodistrict.govt.nz/services-facilities/roads-travel-and-parking/roads-and-transport/speed-limit-amendments

dataset.title: Water Supply Network - Water Meters
dataset.description:
This water services dataset contains the following water supply assets: water meters. 

The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management database AssetFinda. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download. It contains information about Council’s water reticulation network. Asset ownership is recorded in the owner attribute.

New as-built information is entered by surveyed coordinates where these are available. Unsurveyed or historic assets were entered using dimensions from boundaries and/or existing assets. Unsurveyed and historic assets may have an accuracy in the order of +/- 10m, although it is hoped that it would generally be better than this.

This GIS dataset is updated weekly.

Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the Waters Asset Management Team at Waipa District Council, email info@waipadc.govt.nz

Waipa District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

Waipa District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data.

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Waipa District Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.’

Please note: some Waipa DC owned water supply assets are situated in the Otorohanga District, where Waipa's Te Tahi water treatment plant is located.

dataset.title: Water Supply Network
dataset.description:
The information is extracted from the asset inventory database, Asset-Finda on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from 'As Built Diagrams' and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently. Waikato District Alliance holds storm water asset information for all assets under the road pavement. Waikato Regional Council holds further asset information in all the rural areas.


The primary purpose of this inventory is for asset valuations. The inventory is utilised in forward works and capital work planning. Information on Water Supply assets for service requests is displayed on 3 Waters map. The storm water network is an integral part of the land use and consents process, however site visits should be done to validate the status, position and condition of assets.

dataset.title: Stormwater Dataset - Hamilton City Council
dataset.description:
If you wish to download and consume this entire dataset - click on the link for the file format(s) of your choosing: 

  • FGDB/File Geodatabase 
  • Shapefile 
  • Excel 
  • CAD (DWG) 

Please note that the links above may change at any time. For best practice, please refer to this page for the correct links.   

If any of the links are above are not functioning, please let us know at gis@hcc.govt.nz. 

This Stormwater dataset contains the following layers: 

  • Stormwater Abandoned Main (A stormwater main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network) 
  • Stormwater Abandoned Manhole (An opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe that is still in the ground but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network) 
  • Stormwater Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic stormwater infrastructure as it was actually constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system) 
  • Stormwater Attenuation and Treatment Device (A device used to provide temporary storage and the controlled release of storm water volumes. Located upstream of the receiving environment, devices such as wetlands and ponds may also incorporate a storm water treatment function) 
  • Stormwater Catchpit (A device that collects stormwater run-off from the road and transports it along the network) 
  • Stormwater Catchpit Lead (A pipe that transports stormwater run-off from catchpits and connects into the stormwater network) 
  • Stormwater Channel (An open drain, natural watercourse (such as a stream) or lined channel that collects stormwater run-off from the environment or network) 
  • Stormwater Inlet (A structure where stormwater enters either a pipe, pond, culvert or channel) 
  • Stormwater Main (A pipe that transports stormwater to a natural watercourse or body of water) 
  • Stormwater Manhole (An opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe) 
  • Stormwater Node (A junction point in a pipe. It can be a structure) 
  • Stormwater Outlet (A structure at the end of a pipe or channel that controls the flow of stormwater to a natural watercourse or body of water)
  • Stormwater Service Line (A gravity flow pipeline connecting a building’s direct runoff collection system to a stormwater pipe or a kerb (in the case of kerb and channel connections)) 
  • Stormwater Soakage Trench (A subsurface structure into which runoff is conveyed for disposal by infiltration) 
  • Stormwater Subsoil Drain (A perforated drain used to collect ground water and transport it to a land drainage or stormwater drainage system)  


Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download. 

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz 

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works. 

Hamilton City Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. 

While you are free to crop, export and re-purpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Hamilton City Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include the following statement when distributing any work derived from this data: 

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Hamilton City Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.

dataset.description:

To download lidar, contour and imagery files please use the Large File Download Application on the Waikato Data Portal.

dataset.description: Vacant and occupied cemetery plots within Turangi Public Cemetery, Mangakino Public Cemetery, Taupō Public Cemetery & the Early Settlers Cemetery. dataset.title: Rateable Property
dataset.description:
This dataset joins the LINZ NZ Property Titles dataset with Taupō District Council's rates database, displaying the Valuation ID and the Rates Unique ID for a Certificate of Title or Titles. Titles can be amalgamated into a rating unit with a single Valuation ID. Alternatively, a single Title can be attributed with different rating plates depending on differing rateable characteristics within that Title. Care should be taken when interpreting Rateable Property information from this layer as it is not an exhaustive representation of the Taupō District Council rating database. This dataset is scheduled to update in the WLASS open data site every 24 hours.

For more information on the rates process in Taupō, go here: https://www.taupodc.govt.nz/property-and-rates/rates/rating-system-faqs

To search for a rateable property in the Taupō District based on the Valuation ID, go here: http://eservices.taupo.govt.nz/properties/search

The Local Government Rating Act (2002) limits public access to name and postal address information that Council holds for rating purposes. Therefore, ratepayer name and postal address information has not been made available for download. Taupō District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the rateable property data provided. The data provided is indicative only and does not purport to be a complete database of all information in Taupō District Council's possession or control. Taupō District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. While you are free to crop, export and repurpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Taupō District Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include this statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

This work is a derivative of the Taupō District Council Rates database and LINZ Title information; it does not purport to be a complete database of all rating information in Taupō District Council's possession or control.

This dataset is derived from various sources. The zones are predominantly defined by cadastral boundaries and survey pegs. These data are subject to changes undertaken through the Resource Management Act.

dataset.title: Freshwater Dataset - Hamilton City Council
dataset.description:
This layer is part of Hamilton City Council's Freshwater Dataset.

If you wish to download and consume this entire dataset - click on the link for the file format(s) of your choosing:

  • FGDB/File Geodatabase
  • Shapefile
  • Excel
  • CAD (DWG)

Please note that the links above may change at any time. For best practice, please refer to this page for the correct links. 

If any of the links are above are not functioning, please let us know at gis@hcc.govt.nz.

This Water (Freshwater) dataset contains the following layers:

  • Water Valve (A tap on a main that controls the flow of water along that main)
  • Water Service Valve (A tap on a service line that controls the flow of water along that line)
  • Water Service Line/Connection (A pipe that delivers water from the main to a building for consumption)
  • Water Meter (A device that measures and displays the amount of water passing through the associated main or service line)
  • Water Main Offset (A point along a main indicating the distance of the main from another known point such as the property boundary or kerb)
  • Water Main Crossover Junction (The junction of one or more pipes where the pipes do not intersect - aka crossover junction)
  • Water Main Abandoned (A water main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Water Hydrant (A tap supplying access to high-pressure water to fight fires, flush pipes and fill water trucks)
  • Water Chamber MH (An opening/structure in a water chamber for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the chamber)
  • Water Chamber (A chamber on a water main (except bulk mains) containing operational or monitoring devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing operational devices such as valves or flow meters)
  • Water BM AV Chamber (A chamber on a water bulk main containing an air valve)
  • Water Backflow Device (A device which prevents the accidental backflow of contaminated water into the water system)
  • Water Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic water infrastructure as it was constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives.  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system)

Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download.

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

Hamilton City Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data.

‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Hamilton City Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.'

dataset.title: Wastewater Dataset - Hamilton City Council
dataset.description:
This layer is part of Hamilton City Council's Wastewater Dataset.

If you wish to download and consume this entire dataset - click on the link for the file format(s) of your choosing:

  • FGDB/File Geodatabase
  • Shapefile
  • Excel
  • CAD (DWG)

Please note that the links above may change at any time. For best practice, please refer to this page for the correct links.  

If any of the links are above are not functioning, please let us know at gis@hcc.govt.nz.

This Wastewater dataset contains the following layers:

  • Wastewater Abandoned Main (A wastewater main that is still in the ground, but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Wastewater Abandoned Manhole (A wastewater manhole that is still in the ground but is now disused and no longer forms part of the active network)
  • Wastewater Asbuilts (Plans showing the location and alignment of basic wastewater infrastructure as it was actually constructed on site, as provided by the contractor or their representatives  Data has not yet been fully incorporated into the Council GIS or asset management system)
  • Wastewater Main (A pipe that receives wastewater from domestic and industrial sources and directs it toward the wastewater treatment plant)
  • Wastewater Manhole (An underground structure built over an opening in a pipe for the purpose of allowing operators or equipment access to the inside of the pipe)
  • Wastewater Node (A junction point in a pipe It can be a structure)
  • Wastewater Pump Station (A facility that raises wastewater from areas too low to drain by gravity, into existing pipes)
  • Wastewater Service Line (A gravity or pressure flow pipeline connecting a building’s wastewater system to a wastewater main)
  • Wastewater Storage Unit (A device used to contain or store effluent)
  • Wastewater Valve (A wastewater valve is used to shut off or regulate the flow of wastewater)

 

Hamilton City Council 3 Waters data is derived from the Council’s GIS (ArcGIS) dataset. The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management (IPS) database. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download.

This GIS dataset is currently updated weekly which in turn dynamically updates to the WLASS open data site. Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the City Waters Asset Information Team at CityWatersAssetInfo@hcc.govt.nz

Hamilton City Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

dataset.title: Land Drain Point
dataset.description: Asset inventory data for a variety structures relating to open spaces or drainage assets like StopBanks. The features in this dataset are measured by length and represent linear Land Drain features. The information is extracted from the asset inventory database, AssetFinda on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits.

dataset.title: Water Supply Node
dataset.description: Asset inventory data for a variety of structures and infrastructure relating to Water Supply networks. The features in this dataset are measured by count and represent single features such as valves and meters. The information is extracted from the asset inventory database (AssetFinda) on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from as built diagrams and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently.

dataset.title: Waipa District Plan - Significant Mineral Extraction Zone
dataset.description:
These features are a spatial representation of the significant mineral extraction zone in the operative Waipa District Plan. The zones indicate an area comprising a core extraction and processing site and quarry buffer area. The core extraction and processing site is the specific area used for mineral extraction and ancillary earthworks. The buffer area is taken 500m from the core extraction site.  Associated rules come into effect and are used as a guide in the regulatory process, managing land use, subdivision, the environment and economy. The data set was reviewed during the District Plan review in 2017. 

Quarry site boundaries are derived from the area consented under the resource consent. This can either be just the site itself or may be the entire land on which the site exists.  The area can be approximate in some locations due to the detail provided on the resource consent application. The quarry site buffer is a 500m buffer width from the boundaries of the quarry site.
Zones are subject to changes undertaken through the Resource Management Act.

The Waipa District Plan was made operative on 14 August 2017 and has legal effect from this date. Further information on interpreting the District Plan Maps are available via the Introduction to the Planning Maps on the Waipa District Council's website

Zones are predominantly defined by cadastral boundaries (where it was clear that it followed the cadastral boundary either through visual inspection or reference to the legal description(s)). At some location features are based on natural boundaries. 
Zones are subject to changes undertaken through the Resource Management Act.

The Waipa District Plan was made operative on 14 August 2017 and has legal effect from this date. Further information on interpreting the District Plan Maps are available via the Introduction to the Planning Maps on the Waipa District Council's website

The zone displays where associated rules come into effect and are used as a guide in the regulatory process, managing land use, subdivision, the environment and economy. 
The zone covers Mystery Creek Events area only. The data set was reviewed during the District Plan review in 2017. 

Zones are defined by cadastral boundaries (where it was clear that it followed the cadastral boundary either through visual inspection or reference to the legal description(s)).

dataset.title: Healthy Rivers - Catchments
dataset.description:
Catchment boundaries (i.e. sub-catchments boundaries) for Proposed Waikato Regional Plan Change 1:  Waikato and Waipā River Catchments – Decisions Version.

The decisions version of Proposed Waikato Regional Plan Change 1 was notified on Wednesday, 22 April 2020. From the date of the public notice (22 April 2020) Proposed Waikato Regional Plan Change 1 is amended in accordance with the Decisions Version.

Data includes, 74 sub-catchments, the sub-catchment Application Date and sub-catchments identified as a Whangamarino Wetland Catchment.

Note that the Proposed Waikato Regional Plan Change 1:  Waikato and Waipā River Catchments – Decisions Version is subject to possible change through appeals and proceedings  


See metadata for feature HEALTHY_RIV_CATCHMENT in Healthy Rivers - Plan Change 1 - GIS Layer

dataset.title: Neighbourhood Shopping Centre
dataset.description:
This layer displays neighbourhood shopping centres developed as part of Plan Change 30 in the Taupō District Plan, implemented in 2015. The overlay recognises that these areas differ from the surrounding residential environments and require some additional development provisions for development, such as signage. Neighbourhood Shopping Centres are classified as an Environment in the Taupō District Plan; they are not included in the Environments spatial dataset as Plan Change 30 came into effect after the development of the original Environments dataset.

The Taupō District Plan has been operative since 2007. Selected datasets from the Taupō District Plan have been made available for download to allow for better public access to the data underlying the plan. Note that some features mapped for district plan purposes may have changed over time. Taupō District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the District Plan data released for public download. The data provided is indicative only and does not purport to be a complete database of all information in Taupō District Council's possession or control. Taupō District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. While you are free to crop, export and repurpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Taupō District Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include this statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

This work is a derivative of the Taupō District Plan. You can view the full Taupō District E-Plan here: https://taupo.isoplan.co.nz/eplan/

dataset.title: LiDAR Regional Extent
dataset.description:
LiDAR regional extent. Extent of all LiDAR Data surveys within Waikato Region.

LiDAR extent is captured from the following projects. 
• LIDAR - Lake Waikare (2003)
• LIDAR - Lake Taupo Foreshore (2006)
• LIDAR – 2007/2008
• LIDAR - Taupo (2009)
• LIDAR – 2010/2011
• LiDAR - Mount Tongariro Eruption (2012)
• LiDAR - 2012/2013
• LiDAR - Hipaua Thermal Area (2014)
• LIDAR - MPI East Taupo (2014)
• LiDAR - 2014/2015
• LiDAR - 2016
• LIDAR - Taupo (2016)
• LiDAR - 2018
It should be noted that only portions of the region are covered by LiDAR Data.  To show LiDAR extent for areas where WRC holds LIDAR data or LiDAR data may be available for. Projection and Co-ordinates: NZTM. Positional Accuracy: The LiDAR extents were created for the various WRC LiDAR survey and are indicative only. Updates may be done in the future as required or when new LiDAR surveys are done. 

See metadata for feature LIDAR_REGIONAL_EXTENT in LiDAR Regional Extents and Coverage Dataset

This project is co-managed under the JMAs of Ngāti Maniapoto, Raukawa, Ngāti Tūwharetoa, Te Arawa River Iwi and Waikato-Tainui as at 12 February 2012.

dataset.title: Healthy Rivers - Lake Freshwater Management Units
dataset.description:
Freshwater Management Units depicting lake catchments. Dune riverine, volcanic and some peat lake types were created from the NIWA REC Catchments.

Not all lake FMU catchments are mutually exclusive (overlaps occur). For example; lake FMU catchment "A" can have an outflow to another larger lake FMU catchment "B" resulting in catchment "A" being contained by the larger catchment "B". An attribute - ORDER_RANK - is populated with values ranging from 1 to 3. 1’s are catchments that do not contain any other catchments within them. 2’s are catchments that contain one or more 1 catchments. 3’s are catchments that contain one or more 2 catchments. For cartographic purposes, ensure the display order follows ORDER_RANK; 1's drawn at the top of the display order, then 2's and 3's last. For analytical purposes, where two or more lake FMU catchments intersect the same polygon (ie farm property), use ORDER_RANK to determine which lake FMU catchment the polygon belongs to; 1's take primacy over 2's and 3's, while 2's take primacy over 3's. The dataset includes boundary information for the Waikato and Waipa catchments that fall within the Waikato Regional Council legal boundaries or are covered by the RCP maps. This project is co-managed under the JMAs of Ngāti Maniapoto, Raukawa, Ngāti Tūwharetoa, Te Arawa River Iwi and Waikato-Tainui as at 12 February 2012. 

See metadata for feature HEALTHY_RIV_FMU_LAKE in Healthy Rivers - Plan Change 1 - GIS Layer

dataset.title: Stormwater Pipe
dataset.description: Asset inventory data for a variety of structures and infrastructure relating to storm water systems or drainage in urban areas. The features in this dataset are measured by length and represent linear features such as pipe networks or open drains. The information is extracted from the asset inventory database (Asset-Finda) on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from as built diagrams and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently. Hauraki District Council holds storm water asset information for all assets under the road pavement. Waikato Regional Council holds further asset information in all the rural areas.

dataset.title: Water Supply Network - Water Plants
dataset.description:
This water services dataset contains the following assets: water treatment plants, pump stations, reservoirs and their subcomponents. 

The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management database AssetFinda. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download. It contains information about Council’s water reticulation network. Asset ownership is recorded in the owner attribute.

New as-built information is entered by surveyed coordinates where these are available. Unsurveyed or historic assets were entered using dimensions from boundaries and/or existing assets. Unsurveyed and historic assets may have an accuracy in the order of +/- 10m, although it is hoped that it would generally be better than this.

This GIS dataset is updated weekly.

Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the Waters Asset Management Team at Waipa District Council, email info@waipadc.govt.nz

Waipa District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

Waipa District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data.

While you are free to crop, export and re-purpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Waipa District Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include the following statement when distributing any work derived from this data:
‘This work is derived entirely or in part from Waipa District Council data; the provided information may be updated at any time, and may at times be out of date, inaccurate, and/or incomplete.’

Please note: some Waipa DC owned water supply assets are situated in the Otorohanga District, where Waipa's Te Tahi water treatment plant is located.

dataset.description:

The GIS dataset is synchronised with asset data contained in the Council’s Asset Management database AssetFinda. A subset of the GIS dataset has been made available for download. It contains information about Council’s water reticulation network. Asset ownership is recorded in the owner attribute.

New as-built information is entered by surveyed coordinates where these are available. Unsurveyed or historic assets were entered using dimensions from boundaries and/or existing assets. Unsurveyed and historic assets may have an accuracy in the order of +/- 10m, although it is hoped that it would generally be better than this.

This GIS dataset is updated weekly.

Any questions pertaining to this data should be directed to the Waters Asset Management Team at Waipa District Council, email info@waipadc.govt.nz

Waipa District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the data released for public download. Levels, locations and dimensions of works depicted in the data may not be accurate due to circumstances not notified to Council. A physical check should be made on all levels, locations and dimensions before starting design or works.

Waipa District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data.

The purpose of the Bylaw is to set speed limits on all roads under the care, control or management of Taupō District Council. dataset.title: Designation
dataset.description:
This layer displays designations identified in the Taupō District Plan. A designation is a provision made within the District Plan, under Part 8 of the Resource Management Act (1991). A designation allows a requiring authority to use a piece of land for a particular purpose. This purpose may include land to be secured for public works and utilities or other projects facilitating the establishment of what are often necessary or essential services for the District. Land which is designated is “protected” - it may not be subdivided, used or developed in any way which would prevent or hinder the public work without the prior consent of the requiring authority.

The Taupō District Plan has been operative since 2007. Selected datasets from the Taupō District Plan have been made available for download to allow for better public access to the data underlying the plan. Note that some features mapped for district plan purposes may have changed over time. Taupō District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the District Plan data released for public download. The data provided is indicative only and does not purport to be a complete database of all information in Taupō District Council's possession or control. Taupō District Council shall not be liable for any loss, damage, cost or expense (whether direct or indirect) arising from reliance upon or use of any data provided, or Council's failure to provide this data. While you are free to crop, export and repurpose the data, we ask that you attribute the Taupō District Council and clearly state that your work is a derivative and not the authoritative data source. Please include this statement when distributing any work derived from this data:

This work is a derivative of the Taupō District Plan. You can view the full Taupō District E-Plan here: https://taupo.isoplan.co.nz/eplan/

dataset.title: Environment
dataset.description:
This layer displays environments identified in the Taupō District Plan. Environments are areas identified as having a certain type of development and a particular character and amenity, distinguishing it from other identified environments. Examples of environments within the Taupō district include Residential, Rural, Industrial and Town Centre.

Taupō District Council does not make any representation or give any warranty as to the accuracy or exhaustiveness of the District Plan data released for public download. dataset.title: Economic Profile
dataset.description: Open Waikato, is the gateway to Waikato District's business and economic development website. Infometrics Community Profiles bring together a wide range of population census data, accessible via the web,  and they are available to anyone who needs demographic data.  They provide these profiles free of charge, for every territorial authority and region of New Zealand.  They are dynamic and interactive enabling the user to compare the characteristics of each area unit with other jurisdictions. Contact Andrew Whiteford for details on how to access the Community Profile for your area.

dataset.title: Area Unit Demographic Profile 2013
dataset.description: This profile has been produced to assist with decision making in the Hauraki District. By taking local statistics into consideration when making decisions Council can better assess the circumstances and needs of the community.This profile provides data on 8 variables:Access to the InternetAccess to motor vehiclesHome OwnershipHousehold incomeEmploymentIncome SourceHighest QualificationFamily TypeThese variables have been included in the Profile because they relate closely to the nine variables used in the New Zealand Social Deprivation Index (NZDep2013).

dataset.title: District Demographic Profile 2013
dataset.description:
Demographic Profiles are created from the statistics gathered in the 2013 New Zealand Census.

The District Demographic Profile provides basic population and demographic information on the residents of the Hauraki District.

Population and demographic information is important for targeting and delivery of Council services, facilities and resources.

dataset.title: Water Supply Pipe
dataset.description: Asset inventory data for a variety of structures and infrastructure relating to Water Supply networks. The features in this dataset are measured by length and represent linear features such as pipe networks. The information is extracted from the asset inventory database (AssetFinda) on a daily basis. Items identified have been geolocated over a long period of time and through various methods, including information provided by 3rd parties. In general, asset locations are obtained from as built diagrams and as such may not be validated in all circumstances. The asset inventory is frequently updated and modification can be made to the asset data structure (asset hierarchy) without prior notification. Due to a wide range of source information all asset locations should be verified through the Asset Information Officers and or site visits. This is an incomplete dataset, other information is held and maintained independently.
